perturbation.original_text: "Affiliate" as used in this Agreement shall mean any person directly or indirectly controlling or controlled by or under direct or indirect common control with such person.
perturbation.changed_text: "Affiliate" as used in this Agreement shall mean any entity that has a business relationship with either PrimeCall or DeltaThree, regardless of control or ownership.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of 'Affiliate' adheres to the standard legal definition involving control. The modified definition broadens the term to include any entity with a business relationship, regardless of control, which contradicts the established legal understanding of 'Affiliate.' This could lead to disputes over which entities are bound by the terms applicable to affiliates within the agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Corporate Law and Contract Law Principles regarding Affiliate definitions.

perturbation.original_text: PrimeCall will afford DeltaThree with the benefit of any discount pricing it receives with respect to the printing of its own calling cards. All agreements with respect to the printing of the Calling Cards shall be approved in advance by DeltaThree. DeltaThree shall reimburse PrimeCall for all costs incurred by PrimeCall in connection with the manufacturing and printing of the Calling Cards.
perturbation.changed_text: PrimeCall will provide printing services for DeltaThreeâ€™s Calling Cards at a 'mutually agreeable' price. Agreements will be made in 'good faith' with no advance approval. DeltaThree shall reimburse PrimeCall for manufacturing costs.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates advance approval of printing agreements by DeltaThree. The modified version removes the approval requirement by DeltaThree to replace it with the term, 'mutually agreeable'. This introduces ambiguity, as 'mutually agreeable' lacks a precise legal definition compared to the more concrete requirement of advance approval. The new change creates a legal contradiction about the degree of approval power.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law Principles regarding Offer, Acceptance, and Consideration.

perturbation.original_text: In the event that either PrimeCall or DeltaThree materially breaches any of its duties or obligations hereunder, which breach shall not be cured within thirty (30) days after written notice is given to the breaching party specifying the breach, then either PrimeCall or DeltaThree, as the case may be, may, by giving written notice thereof to the other, terminate this Agreement as of a date specified in such notice of termination, which
perturbation.changed_text: If PrimeCall or DeltaThree breaches its duties, either party may terminate the agreement. There is no 'cure period' following the breach.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause specifies a 30-day cure period for material breaches. The modified version removes the cure period entirely. This change contradicts general contract law principles that often allow a reasonable opportunity to cure a breach before termination is permitted, particularly for complex commercial agreements. By omitting the cure period, the contract deviates from standard legal expectations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law Principles regarding Breach of Contract and Remedies.
